title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
Over the past 20 to 30 years, the NFL has changed from run first play calling to pass first; at least that’s the general consensus. Many believe the running game has declined consistently, but others believe that the running game is evolving.
So which is it? I analyzed 20 years of NFL data (2004-2024) to find out if rushing is truly dying, or if it’s just evolving into something different.

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
Over the past 20 to 30 years, the NFL has changed from run first play calling to pass first; at least that’s the general consensus. Many believe the running game has declined consistently, but others believe that the running game is evolving.
So which is it? I analyzed 20 years of NFL data (2004-2024) to find out if rushing is truly dying, or if it’s just evolving into something different.

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
The Data


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(nflverse)

# Load 20 years of data (this will take a few minutes)
pbp_all <- load_pbp(2004:2024)

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
The First Decade: 2004-2014
Let’s start by looking at how NFL teams called plays during the 2004-2014 era.


Code
# Calculate run vs pass percentages for 2004-2014
play_trends_early <- pbp_early |>
  filter(!is.na(play_type), play_type %in% c("run", "pass")) |>
  group_by(season, play_type) |>
  summarise(plays = n(), .groups = "drop") |>
  group_by(season) |>
  mutate(pct = plays / sum(plays) * 100) |>
  ungroup()

# Create chart
ggplot(play_trends_early, aes(x = season, y = pct, color = play_type)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("run" = "#d00000", "pass" = "#0066cc"),
    labels = c("Rushing", "Passing")
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(35, 65)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2014, 2)) +
  labs(
    title = "NFL play calling: 2004-2014",
    subtitle = "Percentage of offensive plays by type",
    x = "",
    y = "Percentage of plays",
    color = "Play Type",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









During this decade, we can see that running plays made up roughly 43-45% of all offensive plays, while passing plays accounted for 55-57%. The balance stayed relatively stable across this period.

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
The Recent Decade: 2015-2024
Now let’s see if that balance has shifted in the more recent era.


Code
# Calculate run vs pass percentages for 2015-2024
play_trends_recent <- pbp_recent |>
  filter(!is.na(play_type), play_type %in% c("run", "pass")) |>
  group_by(season, play_type) |>
  summarise(plays = n(), .groups = "drop") |>
  group_by(season) |>
  mutate(pct = plays / sum(plays) * 100) |>
  ungroup()

# Create chart
ggplot(play_trends_recent, aes(x = season, y = pct, color = play_type)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("run" = "#d00000", "pass" = "#0066cc"),
    labels = c("Rushing", "Passing")
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(35, 65)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2015, 2024, 2)) +
  labs(
    title = "NFL play calling: 2015-2024",
    subtitle = "Percentage of offensive plays by type",
    x = "",
    y = "Percentage of plays",
    color = "Play Type",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









The shift becomes clear when comparing the two decades. In recent years, rushing plays have declined to around 40-42% of offensive plays, with passing increasing to 58-60%. That may seem like a small change, but across thousands of plays per season, it represents a significant strategic shift.

text:
Two Decades of Play Calling: 2004-2024
Let’s look at how NFL offensive philosophy has changed over the past 20 years.


Code
# Calculate run vs pass percentages for all years
play_trends <- pbp_all |>
  filter(!is.na(play_type), play_type %in% c("run", "pass")) |>
  group_by(season, play_type) |>
  summarise(plays = n(), .groups = "drop") |>
  group_by(season) |>
  mutate(pct = plays / sum(plays) * 100) |>
  ungroup()

# Create labels for every 5 years
label_years <- c(2004, 2009, 2014, 2019, 2024)

play_trends_labeled <- play_trends |>
  mutate(
    label = if_else(season %in% label_years, paste0(round(pct, 1), "%"), "")
  )

# Create clean, professional chart
ggplot(play_trends, aes(x = season, y = pct, color = play_type, group = play_type)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 2, alpha = 0.9) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_text(
    data = play_trends_labeled |> filter(label != ""),
    aes(label = label),
    vjust = -1.3,
    size = 4,
    fontface = "bold",
    show.legend = FALSE
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("pass" = "#d00000", "run" = "#0066cc"),
    labels = c("Rushing Plays", "Passing Plays")
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(35, 65),
    breaks = seq(35, 65, 5),
    labels = paste0(seq(35, 65, 5), "%")
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = seq(2004, 2024, 2)
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "The NFL Has Gradually Shifted Back-and-Forth",
    subtitle = "Percentage of offensive plays by type, 2004-2024",
    x = "",
    y = "Percentage of Plays",
    color = "",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold", margin = margin(b = 5)),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14, color = "gray40", margin = margin(b = 15)),
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold", margin = margin(r = 10)),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 11),
    legend.position = "top",
    legend.text = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),
    legend.key.width = unit(1.5, "cm"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 10, color = "gray50", hjust = 0, margin = margin(t = 15)),
    plot.margin = margin(20, 20, 20, 20)
  )









What I find interesting about this is that it is actually the opposite of what people think. Passing and Rushing have stayed stagnant for at least 20 years. So even though the running game hasn’t declined, why do people think it has. I decided to dive deeper into

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
Teams with Elite Rushing Production
Let’s compare how many teams hit the 1,700 rushing yard mark in each era.

Era 1: 2004-2014


Code
# Calculate team rushing yards for 2004-2014
team_rushing_early <- pbp_all |>
  filter(season >= 2004 & season <= 2014) |>
  filter(play_type == "run", !is.na(posteam)) |>
  group_by(season, posteam) |>
  summarise(
    rush_yards = sum(yards_gained, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Count teams with 1700+ yards per season
elite_rushing_early <- team_rushing_early |>
  filter(rush_yards >= 1700) |>
  group_by(season) |>
  summarise(
    elite_teams = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Create bar chart
ggplot(elite_rushing_early, aes(x = season, y = elite_teams)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#d00000", width = 0.7) +
  geom_text(
    aes(label = elite_teams),
    vjust = -0.5,
    size = 4.5,
    fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 2004:2014) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 35), breaks = seq(0, 35, 5)) +
  labs(
    title = "Elite Rushing Teams: 2004-2014",
    subtitle = "Number of teams with 1,700+ rushing yards per season",
    x = "",
    y = "Number of Teams",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 13, color = "gray40"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 9, color = "gray50", hjust = 0)
  )

text:
Elite Running Back Production
Has the number of elite running backs changed over the past 20 years?

1,000-Yard Rushers by Season


Code
# Calculate individual player rushing yards from play-by-play data
player_rushing <- pbp_all |>
  filter(play_type == "run", !is.na(rusher_player_name), !is.na(yards_gained)) |>
  group_by(season, rusher_player_name) |>
  summarise(
    rushing_yards = sum(yards_gained, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Count 1,000-yard rushers per season
thousand_yard_rushers <- player_rushing |>
  filter(rushing_yards >= 1000) |>
  group_by(season) |>
  summarise(
    rushers_1000 = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Create line chart
ggplot(thousand_yard_rushers, aes(x = season, y = rushers_1000)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 2, color = "#d00000") +
  geom_point(size = 4, color = "#d00000") +
  geom_text(
    aes(label = rushers_1000),
    vjust = -1.2,
    size = 3.5,
    fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2024, 2)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 35), breaks = seq(0, 35, 5)) +
  labs(
    title = "The Number of 1,000-Yard Rushers Has Fluctuated Over Time",
    subtitle = "Players with 1,000+ rushing yards per season, 2004-2024",
    x = "",
    y = "Number of 1,000-Yard Rushers",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 13, color = "gray40"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 9, color = "gray50", hjust = 0)
  )
